title: What technology is vastly underutilized in the Star Trek universe? - Quora
tags: Star Trek: The Next Generation (TV series)

response.answer_text: This list is going to be pretty unorganized but are things that I feel would have much more dramatic effects if utilized.  Replicators are nothing short of a miracle. Whether it’s actually creating material from energy or just reassembling items from a collection of stock material, the potential is staggering. Picture this. Imagine someone in the 24th century is told “I have this old landfill for sale. It was covered over centuries ago, but I guess you can buy it for pretty cheap.” Then the guy comes in with a replicator and a front loader, and just starts pouring everything into a replicator. In goes trash on one end, out comes everything in neat and tidy stacks based on material. Gold, silver, copper, aluminum, steel, carbon, silicon, oxygen just gets released into the atmosphere, you name it and the sky’s the limit. Or, the other way around, build a large enough replicator and given enough time, you could have a ship built from just stock material in a fraction of the time. Dump material in, out floats a starship. Sure it would take a lot of computing power, but they have huge computers already, it’s not impossible!  Genetic engineering. I know someone’s going to whine and say “But Khan!” yeah I know Khan was a genetic superman, but who cares? The Federation has the ability to create supermen with ease, and it doesn’t have to be all at once. In a galaxy where most species live longer than humans, are stronger, heartier, and sometimes smarter, it would be stupid to quiver at the idea of putting yourself on the same level or even surpassing them. Imagine a bunch of humans, stronger than a Vulcan and smarter too, able to fight a Klingon hand to hand and win almost every time. A hostile and dangerous galaxy means that the baseline human needs every advantage they can get, and hiding behind ‘morals’ isn’t going to stop the Borg.  Transporter Medicine. A handful of times, Star Trek has shown that people could be healed by a quick trip through the transporter. Just find what isn’t supposed to be there and just remove it. Someone’s dying? Just use their DNA on file and transport them, and they come out the other side good as new. Not sure if it would work if you’re brain dead, but think of the potential. You’re bleeding out, and they want to transport you to sickbay. Why? Just beaming someone up will help them! Sure that leads to the ethical questions of what happens to the original and what happens if there’s a copy made, but let’s be real here. They don’t seem to have these qualms using the transporter, so why not let it heal them and keep them from dying a horrible and gruesome death?  Starship landing. While the idea of a ship built for space landing is a bit absurd, the practical implications are amazing. A starship with hundreds of people can land, which would make evacuations much easier if they needed to get people off a planet or off the ship, and transporting goods would be easier too since you could just land and not be bottlenecked by the cargo transporters. Plus, while Starfleet doesn’t like showing Marines on the shows and movies, there has to be some sort of force capable of that. Landing an entire starship would make offloading people like marines incredibly easy because then you have a starship that can provide cover while the troops disembark and assemble for action.  Speaking of which, ARMOR. Jesus this stuff was hardly ever used, but it should be. These two crewmen look ready to charge in and kick ass with those phasers and armor. They’re not here to play, and they look it. How many needless deaths could have been avoided had they simply worn a piece of armor. Even if it doesn’t stop direct hits, armor is useful in our own real world because it can protect from debris and other hazards on the battlefield.

The technology most underutilized in Star Trek is its signature plot-advancing gadget: the Transporter. You may not think this is the case, since the transporter is always being used to beam our heroes into the adventure of the week. But even just a little thought will tell you that there’s so much more they can do with the thing … much of which would absolutely kill the drama on which Star Trek is based. Such as: Why don’t they store transporter recordings of every member of the crew, in case anyone gets killed and needs to be resurrected?Apropos of which, why bother recruiting anybody for Starfleet service? Why not use the transporter to create clone after clone of ideal crewmen like Mr. Data?Why don’t they transport drones into iffy situations instead of risking people?Why have starships at all? Why not boost the transporter’s performance like Scotty did in the 2009 reboot, and transport directly from one star system to another?Remember the Genesis Device? Why not use the transporter to turn whole asteroids into finished starships as fast as McDonald’s churns out quarter pounders?Why waste time with photon torpedoes? Why not transport nukes right onto your enemy’s deck, or onto his shields?The holodeck is the transporter’s younger brother. Why bother building starships’ interiors in detail? Why not build ships that are giant holodecks?Again, why bother recruiting crews when you can conjure them from the holodeck? (Especially after Star Trek: Voyager introduces holo-emitters that let holo-people leave the holodeck!)See where this is going?

What technology is vastly underutilized in the Star Trek universe? Beaming technology is the top underutilized technology in Star Trek. Considering beaming technology actually transforms matter into energy and then back into matter. Then that is the most important piece of technology in Star Trek. You need Antimatter…Fine. Just beam some matter out of a gas cloud or an asteroid, change the pattern to match Antimatter and you get Antimatter. You need resources to repair the ship…Fine. Beam in matter from something else and make that matter into whatever you need. You need Dilithium crystals…Beam some matter, and turn it into Dilithium crystals. Dilithium crystals would become overly abundant and cheap. You need to surgery to replace something or have something like a virus removed…Again use the beaming technology to go through the pattern recorded and make the necessary changes. Instantaneous healing. You are born with a genetic problem…Again use the beaming technology to go through your matter pattern and change your entire DNA at once. Thus making that genetic problem no longer a problem.  I'm so amazed that most people don't even see the potential in beaming technology and instead choose to whine about the most insignificant things. Even creating new colonies… Think about it! If you created a large enough spaceship. Meant mainly for planetary beaming. Then you could beam a baren or dead planet and change it to be a planet where life can thrive. The entire solar system would be filled with habitable planets. We would have over one hundred Earths on our solar system alone. And millions of Earths spread throughout the galaxy. Beaming technology as it's explained and how it works, does allow for everything I just said. But I guess the show runners must believe that people are not smart enough to think about all the other ways the technology they introduce could be used. I can easily think of at least two to three other technologies that could be used in such a way that Star Trek would take a quantum leap forward in terms of futuristic.

Transporters. Medicine: Beam people up and filter out any toxins or infections right out of them. Or re-materialize them with their bones intact or injuries healed.Waste Disposal: Just beam shit into a local star.Warfare: Just beam bombs into anywhere unshielded you want to destroy.Security: Beam up boarders and then just wipe the pattern buffer. Original question-What technology is vastly underutilized in the Star Trek universe?

As others have said, transporter/replicator tech — they’re actually the same thing. The medical and supply applications are obvious; every ship should have replicators large enough to make anything needed for repairs, including complete consoles for the bridge and elsewhere. But a very underutilized “technology” is just common sense! Consoles that shoot out sparks when a ship takes a weapons hit? Plasma conduits that habitually fail? even if you can replicate replacement parts, those are design flaws someone whould have gotten fixed before Kirk graduated from the Academy.

Not sure if this counts, but the quantum slipstream drive Voyager created. They never worked out the kinks, but it was something I was hoping to see expanded on in either Voyager or another series. It could allow the Federation access to the rest of the galaxy. They could have used it to get past the great barrier around the galaxy and get to andromeda in a few days. What happened to this technology? I don’t know because until Picard airs, all we keep seeing is crap that happens before Kirks era. All the cool shit we see introduced in Voyager, just like the ships armor, and the IP holders want to keep taking the show backwards.

Unmanned AI warships, weaponized transporter use, FTL photon torpedos, FTL manoeuvres, FTL kinetics (accelerate a ELE sized rock to high sub-light velocity, then FTL warp it to proximity of target planet, station, moon or other). All or most in-space encounters are rendered as 2D F2F battles, complete with face offs, swooping fly-bys and so on, despite the fact you have another entire axis with infinite potential approach angles of attack, with integrity and inertial dampening to allow truly aggressive ballistic manoeuvring. The Borg Sphere appears to be the best designed interstellar craft in the entire Star Trek universe. Really, with all the tools available, it is incredibly implausible to have a F2F battle in the first place, all would be stand-off fighting, if any at all due to the ability to essentially 'blink' in and out of space.

Androids in general. All they have really is Data in TNG, and, granted, let’s say he is “special” and unable to be duplicated, still, they could have some other nearly-as-intelligent androids around. There are so many episodes where the ship is commandeered or some spell is cast on everyone and they all fall asleep or get sick or turn into lemurs or whatever. Androids surely could help in such a situation, no?
We’ve never seen how a “terraformer” operates. That or a “weather control system.” On ST: Picard, we’re gonna see flying fertilizer spreaders, as we did in the previews.
